chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with an acute sickle cell crisis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
If an acute sickle cell crisis is suspected:

  • Take a history. Ask about clinical features of the acute complications of sickle cell disease, such as:
    • Pain in the bones and joints
      • Painful, swollen joints may be due to acute bone infarction during an acute pain crisis, or septic arthritis.
      • An infant may present with dactylitis (painful swelling of the bones of the hands and feet).
      • Consider the possibility of acute osteomyelitis, although pain is more likely to be caused by an acute pain crisis than by osteomyelitis.
    • Abdominal pain
      • Consider the causes of abdominal pain that are common in people with sickle cell disease, as well as general surgical pathology. 
      • Consider that pain may be secondary to gallstones (which are very common), ascending cholangitis, acute cholecystitis, gallbladder empyema, or acute pancreatitis.
      • An abdominal sickle crisis is often indistinguishable from an acute abdomen due to a surgical cause.
      • A large and tender liver, pallor, abdominal distension, and circulatory collaspse (infrequent) may be caused by acute hepatic sequestration.
      • Fever
        • A crisis may also be associated with an acute febrile illness due to infection.
        • Fever may present alone or may accompany an acute painful crisis with no signs of infection.
        • Children younger than 5 years of age are particularly at risk of pneumococcal infection.
      • Breathlessness
        • Chest pain and breathlessness occur in acute chest syndrome. 
      • Symptoms of a stroke
        • An acute stroke due to ischaemia may occur at any age but is common in children. The incidence increases with age in adults older than 30 years of age (adults aged 20–29 years are more likely to have a subarachnoid or intracerebral haemorrhage).
        • Neurological complications of a sickle cell crisis may also present as hemparesis, speech problems, seizures, or altered consciousness.
      • Acute renal failure
        • This may be precipitated by dehydration and sepsis.
      • Acute priapism
        • Ask about the length of time since the onset.
        • Acute priapism becomes an emergency if it has been present for more than 3 hours.
    • Examine the person. 
      • Examine for painful, swollen joints.
      • Check the person's temperature.
      • Check the person's pallor.
        • Acute splenic sequestration may present with shock or severe pallor. Because it is most common in young children, parents are taught to palpate the spleen, and they may report an acute increase in splenic size.
        • Development of severe pallor over several days owing to anaemia occurs in transient red cell aplasia and is due to parvovirus infection. See the CKS topic on Parvovirus B19 infection for more information.
      • Palpate for splenomegaly. 
        • On examination, there may be significant splenomegaly, but this resolves by the end of the first decade of life because of multiple splenic infarcts.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based largely on expert opinion in the guidelines Sickle cell disease in childhood: standards and guidelines for clinical care published by the NHS Sickle Cell and Thalassaemia Screening Programme in partnership with the Sickle Cell Society [PHE, 2010] and Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK published by the Sickle Cell Society [Sickle Cell Society, 2008].

History and examination

  • Expert opinion in the Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK is that on emergency presentation, people with sickle cell disease should be assessed for acute and potentially life-threatening complications, including infection, acute chest syndrome, neurological problems, acute renal failure, and priapism [Sickle Cell Society, 2008].

Priapism as a medical emergency

  • The time that is required to elapse before priapism is considered to be a medical emergency differs slightly between guideline groups:
    • Expert opinion in the guideline Sickle cell disease in childhood: standards and guidelines for clinical care is that acute priapism becomes an emergency after 3 hours [PHE, 2010].
    • Expert opinion in Standards for the clinical care of adults with sickle cell disease in the UK is that acute priapism becomes an emergency after 4 hours [Sickle Cell Society, 2008].
  • Due to the risk of cavernosal fibrosis and impotence (which are serious and potentially permanent consequences of a prolonged, untreated attack of priapism), CKS recommends that the shorter time of 3 hours should be considered a medical emergency.
